I'm not sure yet if we'll have to use the quadratic formula in our class, but assuming we do, I tried it for the example problems. For the second one I got an answer that made quite a lot of sense (6.9995*10^-6M=x for the "+" which I accepted). But on the first example I ended up getting 1.5469M for the "+", and 0.738796125 for the "-". I guess I am wondering how I am supposed to interpret that. Should I say that because of how close 0.66667 and 0.73879 are that it is the answer for choice? Was there something I did wrong? Is a question that spits out this kind of answer typically not used? Sorry if this is a lot of words; any help would be so immensely appreciated! In any case, thank you for doing what you do Chad!

Bless your soul, sir! Unfortunately, I am one of the few that is expected to know how to solve using the quadratic formula, but thanks to your little trick, I know how to skip that part (if circumstances permit). Obviously I'll still practice using the quadratic formula, but I know that on the next exam there will be a problem that I can use this neat little trick for!

One trick they would teach you is to have you divide the equilibrium constant by the initial concentration (in his example, 0.1M) and compare to 5%, if the result is less or equal to 5%, then the approximation is justified and you can proceed. If it's greater than 5%, you must solve quadratically.
